text: I thought since I started my career at
Columbia University and I spent my first
five years there I thought I would go
over that with you and tell you about
the trials and tribulations of starting
out as an assistant professor and the
pressures on you and what to avoid and
not to worry and stuff like that so this
is what one of the things I'm famous for
is the Aqsa wall and interestingly
enough the Aqsa wall came out of my very
first publication at Columbia University
so my message is to you read your first
papers carefully because they may lead
to something interesting that you didn't
you didn't actually know here's my first
paper from Columbia University you can
see in those days the graphics were
quite advanced we had to draw our own
diagrams and so forth this was partially
from Copenhagen I noticed that Danish
wasn't on the list of languages spoken I
can add that to the list now since the
only other language I speak other than
English because I went to high school
and Copenhagen that's just in the side
what I want to tell you here is don't
worry about the continuing work that
you've done as a postdoc or a graduate
student particularly if you have
something new to contribute because
there's a lot of pressure on you I know
from agencies and so forth to do
something really cool and new something
that you've never done before my advice
is don't follow that advice do do the
things you really want to do do the
things that you feel more comfortable
with when you get started build on your
experiences as grad students and
postdocs
and believe me you will evolve and your
work will evolve and before you know it
you'll be doing brand new things but if
you try the brand new things too early
before you understand the background and
everything in the context you're likely
to fall flat and flame out and I don't
want any of you to do that because
you're talented 12 and I'm expecting
great things from you well this came out
of a argument I had with my postdoc
advisor Karl Bauhaus and he I wanted to
start ligand field theory because at
that time there was a crystal field
theory in which physicists had taken
over chemistry and they'd replaced all
of our atoms and molecules with point
charges and point dipoles and this
offended me greatly and I told Val
housen I wanted to put the bonds back
into into molecules into chemistry which
is now called ligand field theory he
resisted this because he was more on the
physics side but I talked them into it
and we got started and we published the
first paper together on metal oXXO
electronic structure but he didn't
believe that there was actually a triple
bond between a knock so in the metal
with certain symmetries and certain D
configurations and I told him I said
Karl there's a triple bond there and he
wouldn't let me put it in the joint
paper that we wrote and he told me then
he says Harry if you think it's a triple
bond write your own paper and I said I
will as a matter of fact I already have
and I'm and I'm sending you to the
journal tomorrow and this is the paper
that led to what's known now as the Aqsa
wall so the message is it's okay to
disagree with your postdoc advisor
particularly if you have something to
say it's okay to follow that work and
develop it if you have more to say and
my advice is that's a good thing to do
because you understand this feel better
than then others and so don't try to
just totally change
you're filled immediately because some
agency tells you that that's what you
have to do and then this led to a series
of papers in ligand field theory after I
got started I then wanted to make peace
with my postdoc advisor bauhaus n' and i
wrote this paper and i said why don't
you join me because we got to make peace
now because i have a feeling you're
gonna be writing some recommendations
for me and i and i'm gonna need some
help getting some money so that's always
a good thing to do Alex I see Alex back
there and then he told me he said Harry
I know you're putting the the bonds back
in the back end two molecules away from
the crystal field theory but don't go
too far these these ligands are too
complicated don't work on and what he

carbon monoxide I said they're only
diatomic molecules for God's sakes I
think I can hail that so I did ligand
field theory on this they did ligand
field theory on oxy OHS and then this is
the one I want to tell you the story
Hahn to give you some advice my advice
is be careful when you're dealing with
your first research group and your
postdocs and students because they think
you're better than you are they think
you're God they think everything you say
is right they think everything you
publish is right and so watch out for
that because you've got to tell them you
know you can be wrong and there's a lot
of stuff that's wrong in the literature
and it's it's it's okay to make mistakes
but this fellow manoharan one of my
first students thought I knew everything
I was a professor at Columbia so he
figured I knew everything and so I had
written a paper on the so called
nitroprusside ion which is a cyano
nitrous co I'd written the paper in the

about it which I was pretty sure what's

brought me the data and he said Harry he
says you're right he said sir sir you're
right and I looked at the data and I
said no I predicted the polarization of
the first band in one direction and you
have actually measured it it's in the
other direction I'm clearly wrong it's
oh no sir you can't be wrong
hey you're a professor I said yes I am I
wrong and it took me two weeks two weeks
every day to convince my Aharon that I
that a professor at Columbia could make
a mistake this is the message I give to
you it's very very important to deal
with your students and postdocs in a way
that they feel comfortable telling you
that you know what you just did is wrong
there's a better way of doing this and
believe me it will open new avenues when
you're wrong and you make a mistake and
you go back and correct it new fields
open up it's a it's a great thing don't
don't be afraid of making mistakes and
be sure your students understand that
you can be wrong and that things can get

right books things are a lot more

when I started right after the Civil War
when I started people would call you up

lots of time but I could do things that
I wanted and but if you want to write a
book go ahead particularly if you have
some things to say that are new in the
book but I show you these books just to
show you how things might change
for you I wrote this little book
electrons and chemical bonding because I

cotton wrote this glowing review but
then a few months later I published Mo

so I just show you this to show you that
I'm a human and I can get trashed and
it's it's not a problem
cotton wrote that this book is so bad
the publisher should give away anybody

quantum mechanics and and I'm just

thing let this thing sold like hotcakes
after after people write this review
they couldn't wait to buy this book to
first of all to get a free bottle of

and then this one I wrote because I is a

and so if you do write a book my

advance a field that you've worked in a

and and I think that's pretty good
then you evolve listen to your students
and postdocs because they'll probably

building was a postdoc of mine he came

the first two papers that we published
on these new kinds of sulfur compounds
that had unusual crazy structures and we
couldn't figure it out and these two

these papers are full of mistakes and so
the message I have to you if you get
into a really brand new field you're
going to make mistakes you're going to

plugging keep plugging keep working on
it get it right we finally got it right
in these two papers we finally showed
that these compounds are the first redox

six coordinate complexes were always

things assumed trigonal prismatic
